turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I wanted to tell you my plan.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: So tell me.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I thought I might come back. In the New Year. Under my own steam.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Really? To Italy?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Of course. Let's say, for argument's sake, you were here -- perhaps we could split the rent on a house -- I'll get a job -- or, better still, I could get a place in Rome and when we're there we could be there and if we're here we could be here --

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Oh God, I don't think so.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You see, particularly with the Marge problem, you can just blame me.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Marge and I are getting married.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Yesterday you're ogling girls on the terrace, today you're getting married. It's absurd.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I love Marge.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You love me and you're not marrying me.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Tom, I don't love you.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No, no, it's not a threat, I've explained all of that.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: I'm actually a little relieved you're going, to be honest. I think we've seen enough of each other for a while.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: You can be a leech -- you know this -- and it's boring. You can be quite boring.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: The funny thing -- I'm not pretending to be somebody else and you are. I'm absolutely honest with you. I've told you my feelings. But you, first of all I know there's something -- that evening when we played chess, for instance, it was obvious --

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: What evening?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Sure -- I know, that's too dangerous for you, fair enough, hey! we're brothers, fine, then you do this sordid thing with Marge, fucking her on the boat while we all have to listen, which was excruciating, frankly, plus you follow your cock around like a -- and now you're getting married! I'm bewildered, forgive me... you're lying to Marge then getting married to her, you're knocking up Silvana, you've got to play sax, you've got to play drums, which is it, Dickie, what do you really play?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Frederico!

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Ciao bello.  Don't you want to fuck every woman you see. Just once.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: This is Tom Ripley. Freddie Miles.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Hey, if I'm late, think what her husband's saying!

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Dick -- you've got to hear this!

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Listen, just take one of mine when we get back. Don't worry about it. I did the Forum with Marge and, frankly, once is enough in anyone's life.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Come on, Frederico, do you really have to go back? At least stick around for the Festival of the Madonna.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: I don't think so. Come back with me to Rome. There's this great new club. Have some drinks, lotta ladies...

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Do you think you can steer this thing?

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Just point her at Capri and avoid the rocks.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: DICKIE
turns.text: Marge-maintenance.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Aye, aye.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Dickie?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: It's Freddie. Let me in.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hello, Freddie, it's Tom, Tom Ripley.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Oh hello, where's Dickie? How are you?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Yes, I'm good, thank you. Dickies at dinner. He's at Otello's. Do you know it?

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: I don't think he's at dinner at 6.30pm. If you said he was still at lunch I'd believe you. Incredible. The guy has disappeared off the face of the earth.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: The landlady -- as far as I could tell, the landlady said he was here right now.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: He's gone to dinner! Search the place. I can't think why you would imagine Dickie would hide from you.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Because he's been hiding from me -- what happened at Christmas?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What about Christmas?

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: He was supposed to come skiing. I didn't get a cable or a call or a note or, frankly, a fart.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Of course, he's been very involved in his music, hasn't he? I think his theory is, you know, you have to go into a cocoon before you can become a butterfly.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Which is horseshit. Have you heard him play that thing?  He can't.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: How did you find him? It's such an out of the way apartment. Can I fix you a drink?

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: No thanks.  Some kid at the American Express Office.  Are you living here?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No. No, I'm staying here for a few days, in Rome. That's a new piano, so you prob --

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Did this place come furnished? It doesn't look like Dickie. Horrible isn't it? -- so bourgeois.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You should watch that!

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: In fact the only thing which looks like Dickie is you.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hardly.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Have you done something to your hair?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Freddie, do you have something to say?

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: What? I think I'm saying it. Something's going on. He's either converted to Christianity -- or to something else.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I suggest you ask Dickie that yourself. Otello's is on delle Croce, just off the Corso.

turns.speaker: FREDDIE
turns.text: Is it on "delle Croce, just off the Corso"? You're a quick study, aren't you? Last time you didn't know your ass from your elbow, now you're giving me directions. That's not fair, you probably do know your ass from your elbow. I'll see you.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Most enjoyable. Herbert Greenleaf.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Tom Ripley. Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: I see you were at Princeton. Then you'll most likely know our son, Dick. Dickie Greenleaf...

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Could you ever conceive of going to Italy, Tom, persuade my son to come home?  I'd pay you. I'd pay you 1000 dollars.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I've always wanted to go to Europe, sir, but...

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Good. Now you can go for a reason.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Mr Greenleaf.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Tom. How are you? You look well.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm well, thank you.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Far cry from New York.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Yes it is.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Marge, good morning. Unusual weather.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Yes. What's the detective hoping to find in San Remo?

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: He's being thorough, that's all. I'm learning about my son, Tom, now he's missing. I'm learning a great deal about him. I hope you can fill in some more blanks for me. Marge has been good enough to do that, about Mongibello.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'll try my best, sir. Obviously I'll do anything to help Dickie.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: No, Marge doesn't know the half of it.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I think it might hurt her to know.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: And his passport photo? Did you hear? To scratch out your own face like that -- can you imagine -- the frame of mind you'd have to be in?  I've thought about going to the police but I can't face it. I can't face anything anymore.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I feel guilty. I feel like I pushed him away. I spoke and he heard you.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Well, if we all pushed him away what about him pushing us away? You've been a great friend to my son. Everything is someone else's fault. We all want to sow wild oars. Somebody's got to -- what's the word?  The moment someone confronts him he lashes out. He lashes out. You know, people always say you can't choose your parents, but you can't choose your children.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Tom.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hello, sir.  Marge, you should have waited, didn't Peter tell you I'd come by and pick you up?

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Marge has been telling us about the rings.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You know I feel ridiculous I didn't mention them yesterday -- I clean forgot -- ridiculous.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Perhaps you didn't mention them because there's only one conclusion to be drawn.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: I'm going to take Marge for a little walk, Tom. Mr MacCarron wants to talk with you.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: We could go down to the bar -- no need for you to --

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: No, he should talk to you alone.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Pretty good. Sticking with hot water.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Where's Mr MacCarron?

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: San Remo. The police are amateurs. Well, my boy, it's come to a pretty pass, hasn't it?

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: This theory, the letter he left for you, the Police think that's a clear indication he was planning on doing something... to himself.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I just don't believe that!

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: You don't want to, dear. I'd like to talk to Tom alone -- perhaps this afternoon? Would you mind? Marge, what a man may say to his sweetheart and what he'll admit to another fellow --

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Such as?

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: What a waste of lives and opportunities and --

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't know, I don't know, I just know it.

turns.speaker: HERBERT GREENLEAF
turns.text: Marge, there's female intuition, and then there are facts --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Thanks so much for inviting me tonight.

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: Can you bear it? We hear you're a friend of Freddie's -- he has I hate Opera tattooed on his chest.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: There's room for a whole libretto on Freddie's chest.

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: I'm sure we've met.

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: I was sure we'd met, weren't you, Ted? This is Herbert Greenleaf's boy.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Thanks, yes, I think we did.

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: One minute you people are children and the next you're getting tattooed.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Is Mr Greenleaf here?

turns.speaker: MACCARRON
turns.text: Mr Ripley? I'm Alvin MacCarron.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I could probably see my bedroom from here. I can see my house. When you see where you live from a distance it's like a dream, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MACCARRON
turns.text: I don't care for B.S. I don't care to hear it. I don't care to speak it.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MACCARRON
turns.text: Why do you think Dickie's father sent him to Europe in the first place? Did you know at Princeton Dickie Greenleaf half-killed a boy?

turns.speaker: MACCARRON
turns.text: Mr Greenleaf appreciates your loyalty. He really does. Marge, she's got a hundred theories, but there are a few things she doesn't know. We hope she never knows.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I hope she never knows.

turns.speaker: MACCARRON
turns.text: Three different people saw Dickie get into Freddie Miles' car. A man who won't identify himself because he was jumping someone else's wife at the time saw Dickie removing license plates from a red sports car. The Police know about this man because he happens to be a Policeman.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Pleasure to meet you, Dickie's made a fine catch. I know Emily thinks so.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You were right about the telephones. There are no lines, there's some problem.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Hello Tom. You're off? What are your plans?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Back, I suppose, slowly as I can.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I never said that!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Bird. That's jazz.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Which is ridiculous. Boats are female, everyone knows you can't call a boat after a man.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: He's not a man, he's a god.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dickie, you can't even drive a car! No, what we need urgently is an icebox. What do you think, Tom? Agree with me and I'll be your friend for life.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I absolutely agree with Marge.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: That ring's so great. The green one.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tom, I love you!  See!  I bought it for him, for his birthday.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's superb.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I have to find a birthday present for Frances. Perhaps you can help me?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Frances?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: My fiancée.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: You really should go in, it's marvelous.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: The thing with Dickie -- it's like the sun shines on you and it's glorious, then he forgets you and it's very very cold.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: So I'm learning.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: He's not even aware of it. When you've got his attention you feel like you're the only person in the world. That's why everybody loves him. Other times...

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tell me, why is it when men play they always play at killing each other...? I'm sorry about Cortina by the way.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What about Cortina?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Didn't Dick say? -- He talked to Freddie... apparently it's not going to work out --  Freddie says there aren't enough rooms.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dickie!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'll go and see what's the matter.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I'll go.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hello Marge.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tom, you startled me! You're back.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: How are you? Sorry. Is your book going well?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Yes -- I'm on a good streak, thanks.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I was just looking at you --  so quiet.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Where's Dickie?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I think he's planning on staying in Rome for a few days.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Ha. Did he say why?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I don't know. I don't understand Dickie, Marge, so your guess is as good as mine.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: What does that mean?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Well, one day I'm invited skiing, the next day I'm not, one day we're all one family, the next day he wants to be alone. You tell me.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Is that what he said -- he wanted to be alone?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: He was thinking of you, Marge -- he asked me to deliver this.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Thanks. He knows I love this, although why it couldn't have waited...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Errand number one -- deliver Marge's perfume. Errand number two, pack some clothes and his precious saxophone.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: How long's he staying for?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Search me. I guess we're abandoned.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: He hates being confronted.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I think you're right.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Oh my God. Tom.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Marge, how are you? What are you doing in Rome?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Is he here? Are you with Dickie?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No.  Hello, I'm Tom Ripley.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Is he really not here?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Marge, you know Dickie has I hate Opera tattooed on his chest.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: You were going to Venice.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dickie was at the Opera last night.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I don't believe it. Wild horses wouldn't drag Dickie to --

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: He was there with someone. So I suppose she must have dragged him -- that's not fair. I'm going back to Mongi. I think Dickie's coming home.  I'm going to go home.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Really? That's swell. No, I was just -- you're way ahead of me! Great!

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Did he kill Freddie?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Marge, when did you get here?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tell me the truth. Did he kill Freddie?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'd swear he didn't. Of course he didn't.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I tried again, waiting here, watching for him. Instead it's you. Whenever I look for Dickie I find you.  What happened to your face?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Dickie did it.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dickie?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: My face! There was an argument. I said some things I shouldn't have. About you. About the appalling way he's treating you, all of us. And the next thing I know he's launched himself at me.  Are you getting on?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Get on. I'll take you to him.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Where does Dickie live?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: We passed it a few blocks back, where the police were. The Palazzo Gioia. They don't even know I'm in Rome and I'm not going to incriminate Dickie --

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Perhaps I shouldn't go either.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No, well go if you want to, but don't talk to the Police about my face -- they find out he hit me -- he's got a temper -- he could've hit Freddie.  Good luck, Marge. I'll catch up with you later.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Hello Peter, so good to see you.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hello Marge!

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tom.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I was looking forward to seeing him.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dickie hasn't killed himself. I'm sure of that. There's a private detective on the case now -- a Mr MacCarron -- Dickie's father's employing him.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: That's a terrific idea.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: He's American. He's already discovered Dickie cashed checks for $1000 the day before he disappeared.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Look at me what?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: To the manner born.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Very.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: And you, sir? Any better?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Did Dickie's Dad go?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: He's having an early night.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Poor man.  We were knocking on that door for ever.  I think I've broken my strap.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tom?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Marge, I'm in the bath. Won't be long.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Tom, I need to talk to you. It's urgent.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I found Dickie's rings.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: You've got Dickie's rings.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I can explain.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dickie promised me he would never take off this ring.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Let me put on some clothes and then we can talk about this.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I have to tell Mr Greenleaf. I have to tell Mr Greenleaf. I have to tell Mr Greenleaf.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Marge, calm down, you're being hysterical.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: He promised me. I swear I'll never take off this ring until the day --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Shut up! Shut up!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Marge? Where are you going?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I was looking for a needle and thread. I wasn't snooping. I was looking for a needle and thread to mend my bra.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: The scent you're wearing. I bought it for you, not Dickie. The thing about Dickie. So many things. The day he was late back from Rome -- I tried to tell you this -- he was with another girl. I'm not talking about Meredith, another girl we met in a bar. He couldn't be faithful for five minutes. So when he makes a promise it doesn't mean what it means when you make a promise. Or I do. He has so many realities, Dickie, and he believes them all. He lies. He lies, that's his... half the time he doesn't even realize.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Today, for the first time, I've even wondered whether he might have killed Freddie. He would get so crazy if anybody contradicted him -- well, you know that. Marge. I loved you -- you might as well know -- I loved you, and because he knew I loved you, he let you think I loved him. Didn't you see, couldn't you see? I don't know, maybe it's grotesque to say this now, so just write it on a piece of paper or something, and keep it in your purse for a rainy day. Tom loves me.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Why do you have Dickie's rings?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I told you. He gave them to me.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Why? When?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I feel as if you haven't heard anything I've been saying to you.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't believe you.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's all true.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't believe a single word you've said.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: But I hope that note goes to New York in your purse, for a rainy day.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: What are you going to do now, Tom?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I don't know. Peter has a concert in Athens next month -- and he's asked if I want to go along, help out. He says goodbye by the way -- he's in rehearsal, otherwise --

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Why do I think there's never been a Ripley rainy day?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I know it was you -- I know it was you, Tom. I know it was you. I know you killed Dickie. I know it was you.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Oh Marge.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Dickie? Do you know Dickie?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: You were at the Opera? Well, that explains -- yes I was there. I was there with Dickie.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I told you! I knew it!

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Marge, I don't know you, so I have no right, but Dickie loves you. He's -- I think you'll find he's coming home to you.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: How would you know that?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: He told me everything. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago, so I... I'm going to go now, I think. Unless he meant us to meet -- which would be a little cruel, wouldn't it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Peter Smith-Kingsley. I've heard about you, of course -- from Marge, and Dickie.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: No glasses.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Look there's Meredith thingy -- who's that, Marge? -- They're in textiles... Meredith --  God, how awful, I've spent Christmas in her house...!

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't know her.  He hasn't called, he's hardly written, just these cryptic notes. You don't just dump people.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, we're meeting another friend. Tom Ripley.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Do you know Tom?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We think he's had a change of heart.  So we should be celebrating.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I hope so.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That was moving, wasn't it? When Meredith said --  Meredith's the American girl I saw last night, I know her, at the Opera, she's been seeing something of Dickie --

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: So you found Peter...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I think we sort of found each other.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where's Dickie's father?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: He's not coming till the morning. Evidently his stomach -- I don't think the food here is agreeing with him.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Is this you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, it's Tom's. Splendid, eh?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Golly. Who's paying for this?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: This is spectacular.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's why Tom wanted you to stay. It's better than squeezing into my room, and I know how you hate hotels.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: A hotel would've been fine.  We'll have to tell Mr Greenleaf how far his dollar has stretched.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's funny?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: No, nothing. I'm just thinking about when Tom arrived in Mongi.  And now look at you.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: What's your secret?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: No, it's just -- you are American, aren't you? -- no, I just, I have so much luggage, and you're so, uh, streamlined. It's humiliating.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: I'm Meredith, by the way. Meredith Randall.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Dickie, Dickie Greenleaf. Hello.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: You're not the Shipping Greenleaf's?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Trying not to be. Trying to jump ship.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: So now, did they put your suitcase in the wrong pile? It's just -- upstairs -- weren't you under the R stand? I thought I saw you there.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: My father wants me in New York. He builds boats. I'd rather sail them. I travel under my mother's name.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Which is?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Emily.  Just kidding.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: The funny thing is, I'm not Randall either. I'm Logue.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: As in the...?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: As in the Textile Logues. Trying to shrug off the dress. I travel under my mother's name, too.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Randall.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: But you're going skiing with us Yankees, aren't you?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: At Christmas. To Cortina with Freddie Miles and --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: How did you know that?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Everybody knows Freddie Miles.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Is Freddie in Rome?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Now? I don't think so. But I've met him, of course, and we've chatted and I know about you and Marge and Mongi and what an unreliable rat you are. Freddie said you were a rat and I thought to myself now I know why he travels under R.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I've left Marge, Meredith. And Mongi. So the rat's here now, in Rome.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Sorry, I wouldn't have made a joke if --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Don't be sorry. I've never been happier. I feel like I've been handed a new life.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: The truth is if you've had money your entire life, even if you despise it, which we do -- agreed? -- you're only truly comfortable around other people who have it and despise it.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: I've never admitted that to anyone.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Show me the other one again.  I like them both.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'll take them both.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: I thought you were enjoying yourself?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Let's take a Carozza and look at the moon.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: You're crazy! It's freezing out there.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: C'mon, I need to talk to you. Just the two of us.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Okay then, you're crazy.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Don't worry. Really. Don't worry.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You're such a pal to understand. It's as if Marge is here now -- I look at you and I see her face -- and I can't, whatever I'm feeling towards you -- I just can't...

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: No, I absolutely understand. Of course.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Otherwise you'd be fighting me off.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Beating you away.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Will you meet me tomorrow? Just to say goodbye in the daylight, properly? So it's not just this, it's too... you should always save pain for daylight...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Oh Meredith, I'm sorry. Of course I'll meet you. Let's have coffee in the morning at Dinelli's.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: I don't -- is that by the Spanish Steps?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Exactly. 10.30 --

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Dickie, my God!

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hello Meredith.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: I was looking at you, your clothes, I wouldn't have known you...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Well, you've spotted me and so you get the reward.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Just kidding. Are you alone?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Hardly. I couldn't be less alone.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Of course. Aunt Joan.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: And co. A lot of co. Oh, God, I've thought about you so much.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I've thought about you.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: When I thought about you I was mostly hating you. Where've you been hiding?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I haven't been hiding. I've been in Police custody. They've been trying to flush out Freddie's killer.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: They're letting me have this vacation. Which is why the get-up. Which is why you haven't heard from me.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: You know, the whole world thinks you killed Freddie? It's terrible.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I know. Look, I can't talk now. Later. Later?

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: So -- are you travelling under R?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You know what -- I am.

turns.speaker: MEREDITH
turns.text: Dickie, are you with Peter Smith- Kingsley? I bet you are. My aunt thought she saw him.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Peter Smith-Kingsley? I haven't seen him in months. No, I'm alone.

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: Ho assunto io la guida delle indagini in seguito alla negativa valutazione delle disdicevoli circostanze verificatesi con il mio predecessore Roverini che come e noto non e riuscito a impedire il verificarsi della scomparsa del signor Greenleaf, il quale era l'unica persona al momento passibile di incriminazione del reato di omicidio del signor Miles.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's taken over the case because... they're annoyed the previous chap let Dickie... disappear when he was the only, he was the only suspect in Freddie's murder.

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: Quando e stata l'ultima volta che il signor Ripley ha visto il signor Greenleaf?

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: Dove e stato il signor Ripley da allora?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where have you been since then?

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: All'aperto? Col freddo che ha fatto?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He thinks it's very cold to be sleeping outside.

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: Il signor Ripley ha sviluppate tendenze omosessuali?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are you a homosexual?  Interesting non-sequitur.

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: Non e questo il luogo per le vostre conversazioni private!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A ragione. A ragione.

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: Hmm. C'e questa...

turns.speaker: VERRECCHIA
turns.text: Questa lettera e stata trovata nell'abitazione del signor Richard Greenleaf a Roma.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: They found this in Dickie's place in Rome.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Ditto.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where are you hiding him? He's impossible, isn't he?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes, what happened? I heard you were desperate to come. I was looking forward to rowing you around.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I am. I really am. And I've been travelling. I just can't seem to get that far north.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well hurry, before we sink.  Should I give you my telephone number in Venice?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Will we see you later?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I can't later.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And tomorrow?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Tomorrow's possible. Do you know Dinelli's? Piazza di Spagna?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I know the Piazza di Spagna. What time?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Ten thirty?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We'll be there.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Okay. Marge, see you tomorrow.  It's really good to meet you.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Sorry, sorry. Had to renew my papers. Italian bureaucracy -- never one stamp when they can make you line up for three. Have you been waiting long?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Not at all. Morning Tom.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hi.  Sorry. You okay? You look as if you've seen a ghost...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: My God.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But the point is Dickie -- well we know this -- Dickie loves Marge and he misses her and apparently he's come to his senses...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's fantastic.  I feel guilty. Marge doesn't understand this, but anytime Dickie does something I feel guilty.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Peter, I'm really sorry to put you through this. I just couldn't face going to the police by myself when my Italian's so rotten.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't be daft. It's fine. I'm delighted you finally made it to Venice. I'm delighted, contrary to rumour, you're still in one piece?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What rumour?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That Dickie murdered you and is travelling under your passport. I know, ridiculous.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Welcome to Venice. This place reeks, doesn't it? Can you smell it? Ugh. Sorry. Not the best way to spend your first day.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's okay.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Anyway I've got to the bottom of the delay. Finally. We're waiting for someone from Rome.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What do you mean? They're sending someone from Rome?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That's good, isn't it?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No, but I thought that didn't happen in Italy, that each region was completely separate! I was sure that was the --

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You've seen the papers, you know what a big deal it's been here. American tourist murdered --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's ridiculous but now you've mentioned the stench I can hardly breathe.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: In Rome, about three weeks ago.  I knew that one.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: A Roma, circa tre settimane fa.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I've been backpacking.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't know how to translate that.  E difficile... il signor Ripley... dormiva all'aperto, con un...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No.  By the way, officially there are no Italian homosexuals. Makes Leonardo, Michelangelo very inconvenient.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Tell him I have a fiancée, Dickie has a fiancée and Freddie Miles probably had a string of them.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Il signor Ripley ha una fidanzata, il signor Dickie ha una fidanzata e probabilmente il signor Freddie Miles ha molte fidanzate.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He says so many fiancées.
